speaker: GEORGE
line: We don't have to be out here, you know. It's not like you're still in high school. We can go to the motel.

speaker: PAULA
line: Mm-mm. I wouldn't want anyone to see us.

speaker: GEORGE
line: No one’ll see us.

speaker: PAULA
line: It's a small town.

speaker: PAULA
line: George... Come on, George.

speaker: GEORGE
line: Why'd ya change your mind anyway?

speaker: PAULA
line: I don’t know. You were pretty persistent, I guess.

speaker: GEORGE
line: Squeaky wheel gets the oil, right?

speaker: PAULA
line: I guess so.

speaker: GEORGE
line: What's wrong with right here? I can just set the blanket down and...

speaker: PAULA
line: Not yet.

speaker: GEORGE
line: Why not?

speaker: PAULA
line: Because... You have to catch me first.

speaker: GEORGE
line: Aw, come on, now. You don't want me to chase after you, do you?

speaker: GEORGE
line: Paula! Paula? …

speaker: GEORGE
line: Paula. Where are you?

speaker: GEORGE
line: Son of a bitch!

speaker: MULDER
line: I don’t know, Scully, the man’s vanished. He hasn’t been seen or heard from in ten weeks.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Come on, Mulder, don't you see what they're doing? They're wasting our time. They're sending us on some kind of a wild goose chase.

speaker: MULDER
line: Chicken chase. George Kearns was a federal poultry inspector assigned to Dudley, Arkansas, home of … Chaco Chicken.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm not questioning the case's legitimacy, just their motives in assigning it to us. I mean, doesn't it bother you at all that they're undermining your work?

speaker: MULDER
line: They may "think" they are, but on the night George Kearns disappeared a woman on the I-10 saw a strange fire in an adjacent field.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes, I read that report. She claims that she saw some kind of a-a foxfire spirit. I'm surprised she didn't call Oprah as soon as she got off the phone with the police.

speaker: MULDER
line: Folktales dating back to the 19th century from the Ozarks describe people being taken away by fireballs. It's supposed to be the spirits of massacred Indians.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Those are only legends, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, most legends don't leave behind 12-foot burn marks. That photo was taken by state police in the field where the woman claims to have seen foxfire.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This could have been made by anything-- a bonfire.

speaker: MULDER
line: I thought so too. Until I remembered this. It's a documentary I saw when I was in college about an insane asylum. Gave me nightmares.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I didn’t think anything gave you nightmares.

speaker: MULDER
line: Unh, I was young.

speaker: JONES
line: No...They, uh... See, they took... They, uh... They took me away... They took me away-- the fire demons. The fire demons... the fire demons wanted their pound of flesh but, uh... I'm too fast for them. They cannot kill you. See, you can't let them kill you. Oh, no. Don't let them kill you. Don't let them kill you. That's no way to get to heaven. No, sir. No, sir. That's no way to get to heaven....

speaker: MULDER
line: His name was Creighton Jones. He pulled off the road on May 17, 1961 to take a nap. They found him three days later so deranged by what he'd encountered that he had to be committed. The state police found his car on the I-10 right in the middle of Dudley, Arkansas, … home of Chaco Chicken.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's this, Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's a witch's peg. Staking it into the ground is supposed to ward off evil spirits.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Can I help you folks? I'm Sheriff Arens. I saw you back at the turnoff.

speaker: MULDER
line: We're with the FBI. I’m Special Agent Mulder. This is Agent Scully. Were investigating the disappearance of George Kearns.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: I'm happy to help you but I’m not sure how much there is to investigate.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, Sheriff Arens, a man is missing.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: We didn't find any evidence of criminal activity and since no body turned up we just went ahead and filed a missing persons report.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why didn't you mention this witch's peg in your report?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Because these fields are filled with witch's pegs. A lot of these old hill people cling tight to their superstitions.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about the scorched area?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Illegal trash burning. I keep handing out the citations. They keep doing it anyway. It's cheaper to pay the fine than to haul it to the dump.

speaker: MULDER
line: So you don’t believe it’s foxfire?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Sir, foxfire's nothing more than a ghost story about swamp gas.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: I don't know what y'all are thinking, but George Kearns was passing through town since he got here six months ago.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How do you mean?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Never did fit in-- not at the plant, not even at his own home. It's no big secret that Kearns stepped out on his wife every chance he got.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did he have many chances?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Let's just say George is the type of man you'd expect to go chasing some sweet young thing out of town.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is that what his wife thinks happened?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Push comes to shove, I’m sure she does. But, you're welcome to ask her yourself.

speaker: DORIS
line: My husband had a character that leaves something out. I always knew that about him but I didn't have the sense to do anything about it. I guess he saved me the trouble.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So you're fairly certain that he left you for somebody else.

speaker: DORIS
line: George left me a long time ago. Right around the time I turned 40. Leaving town was just a formality.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you have any idea who he might be with now?

speaker: DORIS
line: No. And I don't want to know, either.

speaker: MULDER
line: This inspection report-- your husband was about to file it with the Department of Agriculture the day before he disappeared.

speaker: DORIS
line: I don’t know anything about that.

speaker: MULDER
line: He never discussed his work with you?

speaker: DORIS
line: He never told me and I never asked.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, he cited several major health violations. He was gonna recommend that the plant be shut down.

speaker: DORIS
line: I told you, I don’t know a thing about what went on in that plant.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did your husband ever receive any threatening phone calls or anything unusual in the mail?

speaker: DORIS
line: Sure. There were hang-ups but I always thought it was one of his girlfriends.

speaker: MULDER
line: Let me give you my phone number. If your husband tries to contact you I want you to get in touch with me. Or if you can think of anything else.

speaker: WORKER
line: Come on, Paula. Let’s go.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: This is Jess Harold. He's the floor manager here. Jess, these people are with the FBI.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Oh, you're here about George Kearns, right?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, there’s a possibility that his disappearance may have something to do with a report he was about to file with the Department of Agriculture.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: You got to understand that ever since he got here George has been trying to shut us down.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well he cited multiple violations.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: I know he did. Believe me, I had to answer to every one.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Was there any merit to his claims?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Let me show you something.

speaker: COWORKER
line: Paula, you okay?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: This is where George worked. Not a chicken leaves here without passing through the inspector's station. We've been operating here for 50 years without any trouble with the USDA. Until George came along.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So he really did threaten to shut the plant down.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Oh, he tried, but we got three other inspectors here who consistently give us top marks. Here, see for yourself. No, the only problem this plant ever had was George.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Problem enough to do something about?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: If you're suggesting any kind of unsavoriness, I guess anything's possible, but you’ve got to understand about George. He had a bone to pick with everyone-- even the federal government.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you talking about?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: He filed a big worker's compensation suit-- claimed he was getting terrible headaches from his job. "Line hypnosis" his lawyers called it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, I read about that. It's caused by high-speed repetitive activity.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: I will not deny that a lot of chickens go through here every day, but we've always operated well within federal guidelines.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What happened to his lawsuit?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Well, it was dismissed just a few weeks before he disappeared.

speaker: MULDER
line: What’s that?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Oh, that... It's a feed grinder. Chops up bone and tissue. See, any part of the bird we can't package we process, use as feed.

speaker: MULDER
line: Chickens feed on chickens?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: I know it doesn't sound too appetizing, but it is nutritious and it cuts down on costs. The meat is cooked and mixed with grain. No reason letting all that protein go to waste.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: You'll have to excuse me. I got a shift change.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Logan…

speaker: SCULLY
line: So, Mulder, are you ready to admit they sent us on a fool's errand?

speaker: MULDER
line: If the fool would persist in his folly, he would become wise, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, whether George Kearns skipped town or somebody killed him, this case could've been handled by any agent under the Kansas City office.

speaker: MULDER
line: I’m not so sure about that.

speaker: MULDER
line: : Let him go. We’re federal agents SCULLY. Everyone stay calm. Don't hurt him. Just tell us what you want. Don’t get excited. Just calm down. Stay calm. We don’t want anyone to get hurt. We can talk this thing out. Why don’t you give me the knife?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You okay?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you have any idea what might have prompted her attack?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: None at all.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No recent complaints or strange behavior?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Paula has always been one of our best employees -- stable, well-liked... I can't even begin to imagine what brought this on.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about you, Dr. Randolph? Do you have any ideas?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: If you're done with me, I got work to do.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: Come by tomorrow. Let me make sure it's not infected.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Sure.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: Uh, Paula came by last week complaining of persistent headaches. She'd suddenly started getting... irritable, unable to sleep.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Were you able to determine the cause?

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: No. I'm just the staff physician. I don't usually treat anything more difficult than a hand injury. I'm out of my depth in psychiatric matters.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You didn't find anything physically wrong with her?

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: I sent her to County for a brain scan and EEG. Both came back normal so I just assumed her condition was stress-related.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Could it have been line hypnosis?

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: Like I said, I'm not qualified to make that diagnosis.

speaker: MULDER
line: But you can tell us whether George Kearns came to you with any similar complaints.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: They presented similar symptoms, yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How did you treat them?

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: I treated them both with pain medication-- codeine.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I think an autopsy on Paula Gray would clarify things.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: I'm afraid I can't authorize that. You'd have to speak with Mr. Chaco.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why? You're a physician.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: Yeah, but Mr. Chaco was Paula Gray's grandfather and her legal guardian.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mr. Chaco?

speaker: CHACO
line: Feeding these chickens helps me clear my mind. They're perfect creatures, you know. We eat their meat, their eggs. We sleep on pillows stuffed with their feathers. Not many people I know are as useful as these chickens.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We’re sorry to disturb you, sir. We realize this is a difficult time for you.

speaker: CHACO
line: You want to conduct an autopsy on my granddaughter. Why? You think Paula had some kind of disease that made her act that way?

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's what we're hoping a postmortem will determine.

speaker: CHACO
line: Thought your business here was George Kearns' disappearance.

speaker: MULDER
line: It is, but we suspect that might have something to do with what happened to your granddaughter.

speaker: CHACO
line: How?

speaker: MULDER
line: We’re not sure yet, but it's possible they may have both suffered from the same neurological disorder.

speaker: CHACO
line: You know, when I came here after the war, Dudley was just a patch of dirt. I built that plant and put my whole family to work there. We made this town one of the biggest chicken processors in the nation. We couldn't have done that with troublemakers and layabouts.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I assume you’re talking about George Kearns.

speaker: CHACO
line: Men like George Kearns don't build things. They tend to tear them down.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Then you're aware of his recommendation to close down your plant?

speaker: CHACO
line: You know, living a long life is a mixed blessing. You spend your youth trying to build something for yourself and your family and your community only to watch it all taken away from you at your old age. Still... I'm not ready to die just yet. You go do your autopsy on Paula. I want to know what happened to my granddaughter.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think we’ve got something here, Mulder. Take a look at this.

speaker: MULDER
line: What am I looking at?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's a specimen from Paula Gray's brain. She suffered from a rare degenerative disorder called Creutzfeldt- Jacob disease. It's characterized by the formation of spongelike holes in the brain tissue.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why didn't this show up on any of her charts?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Short of an autopsy it's very difficult to diagnose. Outside of a textbook I’ve only seen infected tissue once and that was back in medical school.

speaker: MULDER
line: Could this be the reason she attacked Jess Harold?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Absolutely. Victims of Creutzfeldt-Jacob suffer from progressive dementia, severe seizures...

speaker: MULDER
line: Is it fatal?

speaker: SCULLY
line: This girl would have been dead in months.

speaker: MULDER
line: Except that Paula Gray was no girl. This is her personnel file, Scully. Check it out. It says here that Paula Gray was born in 1948, which means that this woman-- Chaco’s granddaughter-- was 47 years old.

speaker: SCULLY
line: There’s got to be some kind of a mistake.

speaker: MULDER
line: Let's find out. Her birth certificate should be on file at the Seth County courthouse. Who knows, Scully? This could be *even* more interesting than foxfire.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The odds that Paula Gray and George Kearns had the same disease are practically nonexistent. Creutzfeldt-Jacob can be hereditary but it's not communicable. That two unrelated people in the same small town would contract the same rare disease is...

speaker: MULDER
line: …A lot more likely than Paula Gray being three years shy of her 50th birthday.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, look out!

speaker: MULDER
line: Call an ambulance. I’ll try to get the driver out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is Federal Agent Scully. I’d like to report an accident on Count A7 …

speaker: SCULLY
line: I just got off the phone with Dr. Randolph. He said this driver had the same symptoms as Paula Gray and George Kearns.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're saying this is a third victim of Creutzfeldt-Jacob? You just got through telling me that two cases would be statistically impossible.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, they would be. I just came up with a sick theory, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ooh, I’m listening.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You saw the feed grinders at the plant. What if somebody put George Kearns’s body in there? Creutzfeldt-Jacob is a prion disease which means it could have been passed on to the chickens and in turn anyone who consumed them.

speaker: MULDER
line: So anyone eating chickens out of Dudley would be at risk?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's possible. You know, sometimes in England they'll incinerate cattle to keep them from passing mad cow disease on to people.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but chickens from Dudley are shipped all over the country. If what you’re saying were true, we'd be seeing an epidemic not just a few local cases.

speaker: MULDER
line: Sheriff Arens? What's wrong with this water?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Runoff from the plant. Chicken litter, mostly. Some blood and parts from the birds.

speaker: MULDER
line: Was this river searched after George Kearns disappeared?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Talk about a needle in a haystack.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I’d like it dragged as soon as possible.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Why would you want to do that?

speaker: MULDER
line: To see what's in there.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Well, listen, that's a filthy job and I don't particularly want to do it unless I know what it is you're looking for.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hopefully nothing.

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, Sheriff Arens, if you don't want to do it I can get some of my men down here to do it.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: I'll do it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder ….

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, it's just a hunch. If George Kearns didn’t run off, if he was murdered for that inspection report then his body's got to be somewhere.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: We closed the spillway, and the water level dropped. They came up with it almost immediately.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did you find Kearns?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Maybe you better see for yourself.

speaker: MULDER
line: Sheriff Arens is outside. They're still pulling bones from the river.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, so far I’ve been able to isolate nine distinct skeletons. This one belonged to the late George Kearns.

speaker: MULDER
line: How do you know?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The pin in his femur. According to his medical file, Kearns broke his right leg four years ago.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about the others?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well. I'll need more sophisticated equipment to be certain, but I estimate that some of these bones are as much as 20 or 30 years old. All of them share one strange detail, though.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, they seem to have lost their heads.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, besides that. The older bones show signs of decay and surface abrasion just like you'd expect but for some reason all of them, even Kearns’s, are smooth and buffed at the ends.

speaker: MULDER
line: It’s almost like they’ve been polished.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It could be from erosion from the water, but...

speaker: MULDER
line: No. That water had hardly any current and this level of erosion wouldn't be confined to just the ends of the bones.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Any theories?

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe.

speaker: DORIS
line: Sheriff Arens?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Doris.

speaker: DORIS
line: Is it true? Just tell me.

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Doris, I want you to listen to me.

speaker: DORIS
line: They found him, didn't they?

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: Well, we brought up quite a few remains at the river this afternoon and George’s were among them. I'm sorry. I'm really sorry.

speaker: DORIS
line: No... No!

speaker: SHERIFF ARENS
line: It’s gonna be all right. Don’t worry, Doris. We’ll take care of you. Doris? Doris!

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: That the new schedule?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Why do I get the feeling you're not here to check up on my neck?

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: They found bones in the river.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: I know. I heard.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: Did you also hear that Clayton Walsh came down with the symptoms? That's four. It's getting worse with every day that goes by.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Someone has to tell Mr. Chaco.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: He knows what’s happening. He’s just not doing anything about it.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Maybe I should talk to him.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: You can try.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: I will talk to him. He'll listen to me.

speaker: DR. RANDOLPH
line: And if he doesn't?

speaker: MULDER
line: I had Danny run a check on all missing persons last seen within a 200- mile radius of Dudley. In the last 50 years, 87 people have disappeared near here and, judging from the forensic evidence, I’d say the same person or persons was responsible.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Then it may have been the work of some kind of a cult.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, I think the good people of Dudley have been eating more than just chicken.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You think these people were eaten?

speaker: MULDER
line: Look at these bones. They've been polished at both ends suggesting they were boiled in a pot. Anthropologists have used similar evidence to prove cannibalism among the Anasazi tribe of New Mexico.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, then Paula Gray may have contracted Creutzfeldt-Jacob by eating George Kearns.

speaker: MULDER
line: That could begin to explain her youthful appearance.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you talking about?

speaker: MULDER
line: Some cannibalistic rituals are enacted with a belief that they can prolong life.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Cannibalism is one thing but increasing longevity by eating human flesh...

speaker: MULDER
line: Think about it, Scully. From vampirism to Catholicism, whether literally or symbolically, the reward for eating flesh is eternal life. I don’t claim to know how it works, but we both saw Paula Gray.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We never confirmed the date of birth on her personnel file.

speaker: MULDER
line: The records at the courthouse should tell us how old she really is and if anybody else in Dudley is lying about their age. You coming?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: You’ve got to do something about what’s happening, Mr. Chaco. People are getting scared. They don't know what to make of things.

speaker: CHACO
line: They're losing their faith is what it sounds like.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: It's getting hard to hold on to the way things are going. Three more have gotten sick since yesterday.

speaker: CHACO
line: I lost my granddaughter in this, Jess, so don't tell me what we're up against. Now, I said I’ll handle it.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: I know you did....

speaker: DORIS
line: I need to see Mr. Chaco.

speaker: CHACO
line: Doris?

speaker: DORIS
line: I... I can't do this anymore, Mr. Chaco. I can't keep lying.

speaker: CHACO
line: It's all right. Jess told me what happened. You have nothing to worry about.

speaker: DORIS
line: They're gonna think I did it.

speaker: CHACO
line: No. They won't think any such thing.

speaker: DORIS
line: But I did. I helped!

speaker: CHACO
line: No. He was no good, Doris. He had no values. He didn't fit in here.

speaker: DORIS
line: But he was my husband.

speaker: CHACO
line: That was a price you had to pay. Now, you knew that from the beginning.

speaker: DORIS
line: But those FBI agents...

speaker: CHACO
line: Ah-ah. This town wasn't built in a day. It's not about to fall apart in a day. You're a part of us now and we're going to take good care of you. Now I want you to go home, get some rest. You've got a funeral to go to. This whole thing will blow over soon enough and you'll wonder what all the fuss is about.

speaker: DORIS
line: I’m sorry.

speaker: CHACO
line: That's all right. We all understand, Doris. Good night.

speaker: CHACO
line: She'll be fine.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: She's not stable.

speaker: CHACO
line: She's one of us now, part of our town.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Unless we do something about her there won't be any town left to speak of.

speaker: CHACO
line: No! No. Once we start turning on ourselves we're no better than the animals. It's the FBI we should be worried about. They're the real problem.

speaker: MULDER
line: Someone’s been playing with matches.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Smells like a recent fire.

speaker: MULDER
line: I bet it’s no coincidence it only hit the birth records.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You think someone was expecting us?

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder.

speaker: DORIS
line: It’s Doris Kearns. I’m in my house. I need to speak with you right away.

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you all right?

speaker: DORIS
line: I'm afraid for my life. I’m afraid he’ll kill me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Who?

speaker: DORIS
line: Mr. Chaco.

speaker: MULDER
line: All right, Mrs. Kearns, I want you to stay in the house and lock the door and don’t answer the door until Agent Scully gets there.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where are you going?

speaker: MULDER
line: To take Chaco into custody.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mrs. Kearns?! Mrs. Kearns?!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mrs. Kearns?

speaker: MULDER
line: Is Mr. Chaco in?

speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
line: I'll see if he's still awake.

speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
line: I’m sorry, but Mr. Chaco is unable to see you now.

speaker: MULDER
line: Do you know what's in here?

speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
line: I wouldn't know.

speaker: MULDER
line: Can you open it?

speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
line: I don't have the key.

speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
line: What do you think you're doing?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, Chaco’s not here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, Mrs. Kearns is missing too, Mulder. I think someone’s been here. The power was cut and the back door was wide open when I got here. But her car is still out back.

speaker: MULDER
line: Chaco must have taken her.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully? Scully! Scully! What happened? Scully! Are you there?

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you all right? Answer me! SCULLY!!

speaker: CHACO
line: What have you done here? I warned you. I said not to touch her. Doris Kearns was one of us.! Who's behind this?

speaker: CHACO
line: Why didn't you listen to me? It's the outsiders we have to deal with, not one of our own.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: We'll deal with them all.

speaker: CHACO
line: Look at yourselves. Look at what you've become. This isn't faith anymore it's just fear. They've turned us into an abomination.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: You brought in the outsider who made us sick.

speaker: CHACO
line: Once you turn on yourselves it's over. How long before it's any one of us? Any one of you?

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: That's not your problem anymore, Mr. Chaco.

speaker: CHACO
line: No.

speaker: CHACO
line: Kill me... And you kill us all.

speaker: JESS HAROLD
line: Bring her over.

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you hurt?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mm-Mm.

speaker: MULDER
line: You all right?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Pending further review, the Chaco processing plant has been closed by the USDA. So far, no evidence of contaminated chicken has been discovered. Though it remains unknown how many citizens participated in the ritual activity, 27 have become fatally ill with Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease. What is known is that a transport plane carrying Walter Chaco was shot down in 1944 over New Guinea. Chaco was the only survivor of that crash. According to naval records, he spent six months with the Jole -- a tribe whose cannibalistic practices have long been suspected but never proven. Naval records also show that Walter Chaco was born in 1902 making him 93 years old at the time of his death. As of this date, his remains still have not been found.
